Miracle-Gro Organic Choice Herb & Vegetable Garden Soil is a popular and well-regarded option.

Regarding fertilization, the potting soil you've chosen does contain some organic nutrients, but it's designed to provide a slow release of nutrients over time. While it's a good starting point, you may want to consider supplementing with a balanced, water-soluble fertilizer specifically formulated for herbs to promote healthy growth and maximize yields.

Here's why:

1. **Herbs are heavy feeders**: Herbs like mint, cilantro, and parsley are heavy feeders and may require more nutrients than the potting soil can provide, especially if you're harvesting them frequently.
2. **Nutrient uptake**: Herbs have a fast growth rate, and their roots may not have time to absorb all the nutrients from the potting soil. A balanced fertilizer can help bridge the gap.
3. **pH balance**: Herbs prefer a slightly acidic to neutral soil pH, and a fertilizer can help maintain this balance.

A fertilizer specifically formulated for herbs will typically have a balanced N-P-K ratio (e.g., 10-10-10 or 20-20-20) and may contain additional micronutrients like iron, zinc, or manganese that are beneficial for herb growth.

You can choose a water-soluble fertilizer or a fertilizer in granular or liquid form. Some popular options include:

* Miracle-Gro Organic Choice Herb & Vegetable Plant Food (water-soluble)
* Espoma Organic Indoor! Herb & Vegetable Plant Food (water-soluble)
* E.B. Stone Organics Bloom! Herb & Vegetable Fertilizer (granular)

When to fertilize:

* Start fertilizing your herbs about 1-2 weeks after planting, when they're around 2-3 inches tall.
* Fertilize every 1-2 weeks during the growing season (spring-fall), depending on the fertilizer's instructions and your herbs' growth rate.
* You can also fertilize at half the recommended strength to avoid over-fertilizing.

Remember to always follow the fertilizer's instructions and avoid over-fertilizing, as this can damage your herbs.

I hope this helps!
